Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Story: I glance at the clock on my dashboard, my heart pounding. My shift as a delivery driver is almost over, but I still have one last package in the back—an expensive-looking box that needs to be left at a customer’s doorstep. The address is across town, and the sun is already dipping low. At the same time, my phone buzzes with a message from my son: “Are you getting the Nintendo today? You promised.” I remember his hopeful eyes this morning, and the guilt tugs at me. I want to keep my promise, to see his face light up, but the store closes soon, and I can’t risk leaving this package unattended or late. My job is what keeps our bills paid, but my son’s happiness feels just as urgent. I grip the steering wheel, torn between the responsibility to my employer and the promise I made to my child, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me as I try to decide which expectation I can afford to let down.
